factoid: The enormous study was full of things evidently in constant use.
The large table was covered with books and plans.
The tall glass-fronted bookcases had keys in their locks.
The high desk was used for writing while standing up.
An open exercise book lay on the high desk.
The lathe had tools laid ready to hand.
Shavings were scattered around the lathe.
The items on the study indicated continuous, varied, and orderly activity.
The prince's small foot shod in a Tartar boot embroidered with silver moved.
The prince's lean sinewy hand applied firm pressure.
The prince still possessed the tenacious endurance and vigor of hardy old age.
After a few more turns of the lathe, the prince removed his foot from the pedal.
The prince wiped his chisel.
The prince dropped his chisel into a leather pouch attached to the lathe.
The prince approached the large table.
The prince summoned his daughter.
The prince never gave his children a blessing.
The prince held out his bristly cheek, which was as yet unshaven.
The prince regarded his daughter tenderly and attentively.
The prince said, “Quite well? All right then, sit down.”
The prince took the exercise book containing lessons in geometry written by himself.
The prince drew up a chair with his foot.
The prince said, “For tomorrow!” after quickly finding a page and making a scratch from one paragraph to another with his hard nail.
The princess bent over the exercise book on the table.
The prince said, “Wait a bit, here’s a letter for you,” and took a letter addressed in a woman’s hand from a bag hanging above the table.
The prince threw the letter onto the table.
The sight of the letter caused red patches to appear on the princess’s face.
The princess took the letter quickly and bent her head over it.
The prince asked, “From Héloïse?” with a cold smile that showed his still sound, yellowish teeth.
The princess replied, “Yes, it’s from Julie,” with a timid glance and a timid smile.
The prince said, “I’ll let two more letters pass, but the third I’ll read,” sternly.
The prince also said, “I’m afraid you write much nonsense. I’ll read the third!”.
The princess said, “Read this if you like, Father,” while blushing more and holding out the letter.
The prince cried, “The third, I said the third!” and pushed the letter away.
The prince leaned his elbows on the table and drew the exercise book containing geometrical figures toward him.
The prince began, “Well, madam,” while stooping over the book close to his daughter.
The prince placed an arm on the back of the chair on which the princess sat.
The princess felt surrounded on all sides by the acrid scent of old age and tobacco.
The prince said, “Now, madam, these triangles are equal; please note that the angle ABC...”
The princess looked at her father’s eyes glittering close to her in a scared way.
The red patches on the princess’s face came and went.
The princess understood nothing and was so frightened that her fear prevented her understanding any of her father’s further explanations, however clear they might be.
The princess’s eyes grew dim.
The princess could not see and could not hear anything.
The princess was only conscious of her stern father’s withered face close to her, of his breath and the smell of him.
The princess could think only of how to get away quickly to her own room to make out the problem in peace.
The old man moved the chair on which he was sitting noisily backward and forward.
The old man made efforts to control himself and not become vehement.
The old man almost always became vehement, scolded, and sometimes flung the exercise book away.
The princess gave a wrong answer.
The prince shouted, “Well now, isn’t she a fool!” while pushing the book aside and turning sharply away.
The prince rose immediately, paced up and down, lightly touched his daughter’s hair, and sat down again.
The prince drew up his chair and continued to explain.
The prince said, “This won’t do, Princess; it won’t do,” when Princess Mary had taken and closed the exercise book with the next day’s lesson and was about to leave.
The prince said, “Mathematics are most important, madam! I don’t want to have you like our silly ladies. Get used to it and you’ll like it,” and patted her cheek.
The prince said, “It will drive all the nonsense out of your head.”
The princess turned to go.
The prince stopped her with a gesture and took an uncut book from the high desk.
The prince was an old man.
The prince had a bristly cheek that was as yet unshaven.
The prince had sound yellowish teeth.
The prince had a cold smile.
The prince had a small foot in a Tartar boot embroidered with silver.
The prince had a lean sinewy hand.
The prince had a hard nail.
The princess had a timid glance and a timid smile.
The princess had a scared look.
The princess had a fear.
The princess had red patches on her face when she saw the letter.
The princess had a wrong answer.
